text:
Off access areas in video games are always
going to pull me right in.
If I can see it, I want to explore it.

Those of you watching probably carry a similar
thought process.

The world’s of games have so much to them
that we never get to experience, and it’s

fascinating to find the things that have laid
dormant for years out of reach.

When we’re tackling worlds the size of galaxys,
there’s quite a lot to explore.

And that’s where we once again find ourselves
today…

On the edges of space, fixated on something
quite strange.

Today we’ll be taking a deep dive into a
place that I’ve been wanting to talk about

for a while now, but have only really highlighted
the strange occurrences that happened around
this particular location.
We’re heading back to Bowser’s Star Reactor…

And diving headfirst into the strange interior
of Bowser’s inaccessible warships.

Bowser’s Star Reactor is a strange level
for a lot of different reasons.

For those who have followed the channel for
a while now, you’ll know that this is where
Worm Hole traveling was first discovered.

In fact, it was discovered just along the
edges of the area we’ll be talking about.

I utilize flying hacks very often in the Galaxy
games so that we can get an in-person viewpoint
of places we can’t normally go.

We could of course just move our camera there
if we wanted to, but a tangible game world

is far more interesting to me than one that
is intangible.

The premise of the flying hack is it basically
enables the flying ability that is granted

within Rosalina’s Observatory anywhere in
the game.

It’s normally only useable here, but it’s
still able to be activated by modifications.

It exists in the code for Super Mario Galaxy
2 as well, which is why we can utilize it
in that game too.

Anyways, we want to head into the fountain
area and shoot toward’s Bowser’s giant
head floating in space.

As we fly into Bowser’s reactor, we’re
able to see a set of warships behind us in
the distance.

Upon landing, we can’t quite look at them
head on completely due to the angle they are
at.

There’s actually two sets of them, and the
ones above us are too high to see.

This is where we want to boot up our flying
hack and take to the skies.

Upon approaching the first set of ships, we
notice something is definitely strange.

It’s almost as if they are standing up straight,
perfectly balanced on the nose of the ship.

If we land on these ships, we definitely have
to be careful so we don’t slide off to our
death.

Honestly, about the only places we can stand
in the first set of ships are on the masts

of the propellers and the back of the ship
itself.

Due to the rotation of the ship, the stair
stepping effect of the ships top area actually

is oriented in a way that makes us slide off
continually.

If it was rotated the other way, we’d be
able to walk along the edges of the flooring.

Moving to the back of the ship, we can actually
move inside of the propellers without Mario
losing his head.

Since you normally are sort of pushed away
from a ship if you were to fall off it in

normal gameplay, Mario never really comes
in contact with these blades.
So it is neat to see them from this perspective.

However, this first set of ships aren’t
really the most interesting out of the bunch.

When I explored these for the first time,
back in the first quarter of 2018, that’s
when I discovered the strange Wormhole exploit.

Traveling between these two sets of ships,
going from the front set to the back, is when
I made the leap into deep space.

There’s a gravity range off to the far right
here that inverts gravity, and when I hit

it at the precise moment, I traveled about
5 to 10 minutes out of bounds or so.

It was quite strange, and I spent the next
year or so trying to figure out how it actually
occurred.

I recommend watching my video on it if you
haven’t seen it already.

But anyways, this next set of ships is honestly
the more interesting of the two.

Because for some reason, one of these ships
were going to next allows you to go inside
of it.

As we fly to this next set of ships, it becomes
apparent that they aren’t oriented the same
way as the others.

They aren’t standing on the nose of the
ship, but they are rotated 90 degrees to their
side.

Because of this, we can actually walk alongside
the cannons that poke out from below.

The side of the ship doesn’t actually have
unique collision at all, and the cannons are
just inside a glass box basically.

The propellers in the back have an edge though,
and it prevents Mario from walking into them.

On both of the outer ships down here, there
are doors on the ship that cannot be opened
no matter what we do.

It is pretty neat trying to figure out how
to navigate around them though, and utilizing

wall sliding mechanics to get to the lower
levels.

However, the middle ship down here is by far
the coolest of them all.

And that’s because there’s a hole on the
back part of the ship’s deck.

Traveling over to the middle part of this
ship reveals that the two closed doors are

open as well, but we can’t actually go inside
them despite being able to use the ships steps
as ledges.

But the hole on the back of the ship can be
entered.

If we make our way down to the bottom rung
of the ship’s edge and flip up into the

hole, we’ll find ourselves in a room we’re
not supposed to be in.

It’s a bit trippy though because the room
is of course sideways, and the camera doesn’t
know how to behave properly.

There are three closed doors in the interior
of the ship that we can’t do anything with,

however, there is an anchor in the back of
the ship we can walk on.

It’s kind of neat to think about this strange,
forgotten anchor that’s been floating out
here for ages.

Beyond that - the concept of an anchor for
an these types of airships is super strange.
For one, they’ve never anchored onto anything.

And two, they have never needed an anchor
because they float perfectly in place without
any hint of wandering off.
They’re definitely a work of art.

Anyways, this anchor can actually be used
as a ramp to go into another door…
Or so it looks that way.

Unfortunately, the hall way it leads to is
blocked off and the door cannot actually be
entered.

We can see that this wraps around deeper into
the ship though if we take the camera for
a spin.
In fact, it actually connects outside.

So if we re-arrange ourselves and make it
out of the hole we first came in, we can actually

utilize our flying hack to go out and around
the ship and into the silver pipe that protrudes
out of it.

Doing this allows us to walk back through
the “closed off” texture inside the pipe,
and back into the ship.

The camera gets stuck unfortunately so we
have to move it to make sure it follows us.

Walking in this metal tunnel is pretty difficult
because we can only walk in the absolute bottom
of it.

Trying to move elsewhere in the tunnel makes
Mario get stuck in a continual sliding animation.

When combined with the awkward camera we’re
using, it’s easy to get stuck in one spot
for quite a while.

We can of course use this tunnel to connect
back into the main room we were in before,

and upon doing so, we pass through a one-sided
barrier and can’t go back.

So this doorway we were looking at before
does work - but only from one direction.

Some of you may recognize this ship setup
from another level - which honestly, I’m

drawing a blank right now while writing this
script.

So if you remember the level in which you
fall down into the bottom of this ship, let
me know in the comments.

In the files this ship is labeled as KoopaShipC
- and normally it is supposed to have a seesaw
attached to the top of it.

That object isn’t loaded in though, so we
don’t have one.

For the fun of it, I brought this ship to
our starting location and orientated it in

a way that wouldn’t kill or hinder us from
entering.

We’re able to jump to it now and walk around
it like normal.

We can go inside and check out the room the
way it is supposed to be, and we can even
enter the pipe outside.

With this orientation, the grey pipe behaves
correctly and it actually causes us to slide

straight into the interior of the ship as
intended.

To make things even more strange, alongside
this ship I decided to park a different ship.

A ship with its scale all thrown out of whack
- hence why it looks all sorts of messed up.

I also dropped down a lava ball from the end
of the level here too.

Then crashed another ship into this ship,
because why not.

Climbing upon this monstrosity is really strange
because the scale isn’t uniform.

The length is four times as long as the height,
and the depth is twice as long as the height.

The object scales up in game, but the collision
is broken.

We’re basically surrounded by invisible
walls that lock us into parts of the ship.
They are often too high to jump over too.

I imagine this is because the scaling isn’t
uniform.

If we approach the edges of the ship we just
fall right through them.

We can board the crashed ship though, although
the gravity just makes us slide like a mad
man.

One last interesting thing to talk about is
that the lava spheres that are at the end
of the level, actually don’t have any collision.

We don’t get burned or get pulled to their
surface.

They’re merely for show, which makes sense
because we can’t make it over to them at
all in real gameplay.

All in all, I have a lot of weird memories
with this level.

Exploring these tilted warships was pretty
thrilling the first time I did so, especially
after discovering the one could be entered.

But beyond that, knowing that I triggered
my first wormhole warp in this level makes
me remember it even more so.

Traveling thousands of meters in a split second
definitely caught me off guard and won’t
be something I'll ever forget!
Thanks for tuning in for this battleship tour!

I’ve been waiting to make this one for a
while, so I hope you enjoyed it.
As always, drop a like if you did.
Thanks for watching guys and gals, and until my next video, cheers!
